3.author: zanne61
3.body:
I've been to a few Broadway musicals just before 911 and worked at brokerage firms for years so feel some connection there. Just driving through (daughter drove) was overwhelming and so amazing.  I would have been solo if I'd stayed over and I wasn't mentally prepared to get from airport to memorial and back by myself.
Did take solo trip to Niagara Falls last spring and absolutely loved it. Not many places I'd go back to but felt like I didn't have enough time. Just did 2 night stay.

7.author: munnexdio
7.body: This building will most likely need major repairs in the spring. There’s thousands of pounds of snow on it/against it and it can absolutely destroy a building

7.author: munnexdio
7.body: This will need to be shoveled out by hand to an extent. The roof will need to be hand shoveled. But with how buried it is, it will need to melt a few feet before any work can be done on it. It will take months of warm temperatures to melt this. If nobody tries to shovel it at all, it will still have snow on it in July or August. It’s not a fast melting process. The hottest temperatures we get in the summer are about 80° in the sun. It’s often 65-70°. We will have snow in forested/shady areas at higher elevations through August or September

7.author: munnexdio
7.body: The Sierra Nevada mountains in California

12.author: 1ofZuulsMinions
12.body:
I said it ended during the COVID 19 lockdown. It actually began at my particular building March of 2020. It did not become a full company-wide policy for all facilities until summer of 2021. 

If you actually knew anything Amazon, you’d know that different facilities have different sets of rules, especially ones in other countries. For example, in America we aren’t allowed to have chairs at most FCs (with a few exceptions), but in Europe, they can. 

You may SHOCKED to learn that different countries have different laws! 😱And you might also wanna check your math, because there’s a difference between addition and subtraction. It’s pretty hilarious that the only way you can think to troll me is to point out that I made an accurate correction to a date. 😂

Anyways, I backed my anecdotes with facts and links, still waiting to hear about your tenure with the company you know so much about…. But I highly suspect that youve never worked here ever, and only know what you read in clickbaity Buzzfeed headlines. Prove me wrong.

Edit to add: https://www.nbcnews.com/business/business-news/california-passes-bill-targeting-amazon-s-productivity-quotas-can-penalize-n1278807

I had a good time there. This one looks like the one in Los Angeles and there's another in New Orleans.

18.author: My_Books_are_Calling
18.body:
The one OP is at is in LA. It’s the better of the two. 

I’ve been to both and while NOLA is bad, this one has a much bigger and diversified collection.

18.author: My_Books_are_Calling
18.body:
Museum of Death is a museum that is about serial killers showing murderabillia (LA had a Pogo the clown painting, Manson family made quilt, et) papers (black dahlia case notes, etc) and item (an electric chair used on death row) about mass suicides (heavens gate items, Jonestown, etc) antique mortuary items and more.  They even have the mummified head of a famous 1922 French serial killer. 

If you’re into the darker side of life, it’s a great place to visit. 

https://theculturetrip.com/north-america/usa/california/articles/las-museum-of-death-is-graphic-ghoulish-and-kind-of-gross/

18.author: My_Books_are_Calling
18.body:

20.author: timberwolf0122
20.body:
It’s amazing what resources are at your disposal with a little lateral thinking.

My process would be as follows

1) find hiding spots, I’ll need this incase of room/cell inspection
2) what’s materials do I have? Fabrics, threads, what is the bed made of, is there an outlet or light switch in the room, furniture what is it made of? Etc. 
3) tools. What do I have and what can I make? This may be a multistep part as I may need to make a tool to make a tool.
4) protocols and procedures. When is the there a weak spot I can exploit to escape?
5) location and weather. Where am I, how’s hostile is it? What do I need to survive outside?
6) how long do I need to survive? Where will I go when I escape and how long do I need to survive?

It’s a little crude but that’s the essential frame work

20.author: c0t0d0s1
20.body:
Where I was there, the staff had to do rounds on every patient every 15 minutes, 24/7. No one told me, so the first night I couldn’t figure out why someone kept coming in my room with a flashlight. 

The bed, desk, and wardrobe in my room was epoxied to the walls. The chair was an oversized plastic Fisher-Price looking thing that was too heavy to lift. 

All door handles were ligature-resistant, as were the towel hooks, shower head, faucets, and even the toilet paper holder. 

In the common areas, the flat screen TVs were enclosed in a full metal jacket with a shatter-proof plexiglass screen that could withstand the impact of a sofa.

The facility was in southeastern Wisconsin and I was there during winter, so trying to run without shoes would be a challenge.

29.author: 30mil
29.body:
In most jobs, it would not be acceptable for a biological woman to look like this. Notice you rarely see women in daily life who look like drag queens.

To put it in perspective, we could look at another example of an oppressor group -- white people -- dressing up as exaggerated, cartoonish versions of black people -- like with blackface in minstrel shows.

29.author: ElDiavoloPiccolo
29.body:
In jobs, yes. But in private, no. And we talk about parties, which is private. 

Comparing blackfacing to choice of clothing??? Bro, c'mon you start to make yourself look like a fool here. I tried to argue with common sense, but I give up. You're right.

29.author: 30mil
29.body: Choice of clothing? Drag involves painting your face (like blackface), dressing up in a costume, and behaving in a certain way to put on a show. These are also true of minstrel shows.

29.author: ElDiavoloPiccolo
29.body:
TIL: makeup = blackfacing. Have bad news for 99% of the women then, too... Been to Britain before? Out of 100 women, there are at least five of them wearing the exact same stuff in their faces. And carneval is also illegal and painting butterflies and whiskers on kids' faces and circus and literally all other shows, or even traditional tribal whitefacing.... Stop it with your elementary school arguments. You're just pissed because it's a man and you don't like how he looks/behaves... We all know that this is the reason. You're just too dishonest to yourself to accept your hatred. Keep on fooling yourself, it doesnt't work with other humans capable of thinking tho.

The only thing that counts is: You're full of hate and never learned what "live and let live" really means. But you gotta see the good here: you didn't make yourself look like the totle arse you are in real life, but anonymously. Take the chance and learn from it, before a drag queen knocks out all your teeth xD

29.author: 30mil
29.body: Yes, blackface is black make-up. Drag queens aren't doing make-up like real women. They're doing exaggerated, cartoonish versions (like how black people aren't literally black with huge red lips). Think of the difference between a trans woman and a drag queen. One is a regular woman and the other is a cartoon.

45.author: StrawberryLovery
45.body:
It can stand up to the strongest, most literally demonic forces actually hell-bent on opposing it.

The question is -- is it really appropriate to have that debate given the time and place and general social considerations of not wanting to offend other people.

45.author: ActualChamp
45.body: I feel like it wasn't as bad as you feel like it was. I mean, you're allowed to feel that way, but it's not like he's talking directly to someone whose son died and telling them "he's not going to heaven because heaven doesn't exist." There's nothing especially special about this time or place.

45.author: StrawberryLovery
45.body:
No. This time and place is different since it's a very sad story and even sadder when you learn the boy died shortly after from leukemia.

For many, the religious instinct is their coping mechanism when it feels all is lost because under that framework, their life had meaning, and the suffering is redeemed. The alternative suggests there's no point to it, and conveying so to a grieving person is quite insensitive and lacks empathy.

45.author: ActualChamp
45.body:
Some people cope by coming to terms with the lack of an afterlife. Why is that reaction not appropriate for the situation? You don't even know if the boy's family is religious or not, so you don't know if anyone meaningfully affected by this situation would be upset by this random person's take on the world, just other internet commenters.

There can absolutely be meaning to life even if the life wasn't created with some grand purpose in the mind of a supernatural, godly being. Some people consider meaning to be a personal and individual thing rather than a spiritual thing. How you find that meaning has nothing to do with empathy.

45.author: StrawberryLovery
45.body:
>You don't even know if the boy's family is religious or not

Exactly, hence my original rule of not talking about religion or politics. It's best to avoid such topics altogether if you know people have strong feelings about it and you don't know which side of it they're on. Invalidating the person's feelings, especially when told as "unproven and baseless beliefs" is quite insensitive and may show a lack of empathy. Knowing the same beliefs are their coping mechanism, debating or criticizing it at that point in time isn't exactly the right thing to do.

45.author: ActualChamp
45.body:
I think it's important to bring these things up *because* people have such strong feelings about them.

Religion isn't just a hobby or a passion that has no influence on others or yourself outside of how you arbitrarily find your enjoyment. It affects your behaviors, your treatment of others, and your general approach to life. Same goes with politics. Nothing you believe regarding either of those topics is in a bubble—it's all important.

The thing about religion is that it hinges on faith and belief. As a religious person, and I would hazard as to guess that you have a belief in some kind of Abrahamic religion, probably some form of Christianity based on your responses, you probably understand that one of the challenges you have to face is that you must have *faith* in something that is not always made immediately clear to you. The very fact that much of your religion is scientifically unproven and baseless outside of cultural legend is one of the challenges you need to reconcile with as a believer. I'm not invalidating your beliefs with that statement, it's just a matter of fact and is literally something that is said by religious leaders in communities like yours. I speak from experience here.

The person you're replying to who said that these circumstances challenge their belief and overpower their willingness to believe in an all-loving God is valid and important to them. It doesn't necessarily automatically influence or invalidate your beliefs. The only thing that does that is looking at their argument and dismissing it wholesale without allowing it to challenge your understanding of your religion and approach it with deeper reflection and empathy.

Additionally, the Problem of Evil is one of the most basic criticisms of the concept of an all-loving God, and if an all-loving God is a key component of what you believe and you want to be honest and confident in yourself and those beliefs, then you need to be prepared to face those arguments.

46.author: techmouse7
46.body: My aunt does this move in church too

46.author: Huge-Impression2734
46.body: Wow...I never knew they do it in the church

46.author: techmouse7
46.body: I mean I’m pretty sure it’s just a few people but my family is Baptist lol

47.author: adrolter
47.body: Yup, I've done that. Don't trust it to thoroughly clean and rinse the inner corners of the bag, at least not with my dishwasher that doesn't have a dedicated upper spray arm.

47.author: Blahblah778
47.body:
>That's literally human nature.

In a capitalist society, sure. Innately? Absolutely not.

47.author: adrolter
47.body:
Innately, yes. That's the definition of human nature and what I meant.

Unless you can magically eliminate scarcity, I guess?

47.author: adrolter
47.body: Always happy to learn something new...

47.author: Blahblah778
47.body:
Humans have foresight. Ancient cultures knew not to over hunt an area, because then in the future that food source would run dry.

I'm not saying it's human nature to be a perfect natural conservationist, but I don't think there's any evidence that it's literally **human nature** to be greedy above all else. 

It's perfectly within our facilities to plan for and care about the future. Modern society pushes us to care about ourselves in the present first, by necessity.

48.body: The Vet was demolished 19 yrs ago so I can't guess what you mean but sure hope you had a great time.
